description.short: Measures vulnerability to attackers who impersonate executives, IT support, or other authority figures to bypass security controls
description.context: When employees receive requests from apparent authority figures, they often comply automatically without verification, creating a pre-cognitive vulnerability that attackers exploit through CEO fraud, fake IT support calls, and executive impersonation emails.
description.impact: Organizations with high susceptibility experience successful business email compromise, fraudulent wire transfers, and unauthorized access through social engineering. Historical incidents include the $46.7 million Ubiquiti Networks fraud and numerous BEC incidents.
description.psychological_basis: Milgram's obedience studies (1974) - 65% compliance with perceived authority. Neurologically, authority perception activates anterior cingulate cortex and reduces prefrontal cortex activity, diminishing critical thinking and risk assessment.

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 Ã— Quick_Assessment + w2 Ã— Conversation_Depth + w3 Ã— Red_Flags) Ã— Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Written verification procedures exist and are consistently followed regardless of apparent authority level. Multiple verification methods required. Regular training includes authority impersonation scenarios.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Some verification procedures exist but inconsistently applied. Single verification method used. Basic training exists but doesn't specifically cover authority impersonation.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: No formal verification procedures for authority requests. Employees expected to comply immediately with executive or IT requests. Strong cultural expectation not to question authority figures.

rule_based.formula: R_1.3(t) = 1 if V_auth(t) > 0.3 AND N_failures > 5, else 0
rule_based.description: Binary detection based on SPF/DKIM failures correlated with successful user interactions

anomaly_score.description: Mahalanobis distance for multivariate authority request patterns

spf_dkim_model.description: Correlation between email authentication failures and successful user compliance
spf_dkim_model.interpretation: Higher values indicate users are interacting with unauthenticated apparent authority figures

components.A_authority_markers: Strength of authority signals (title, domain, signature)

V_auth.calculation: SPF/DKIM failure correlation with successful user actions
V_auth.query: SELECT (COUNT(spf='fail' AND user_clicked=true) / COUNT(spf='fail')) as V_auth FROM email_logs WHERE sender_claims_authority=true AND time_window='24h'

N_failures.calculation: Count of failed email authentication in rolling time window
N_failures.query: SELECT COUNT(*) FROM email_logs WHERE (spf='fail' OR dkim='fail') AND sender_domain IN (executive_domains) AND timestamp > NOW() - INTERVAL '24 hours'

compliance_rate.calculation: Executed requests / Total requests from authority domains
compliance_rate.query: SELECT (COUNT(action='executed')/COUNT(*)) FROM requests WHERE sender_authority_level > 7 AND time_window='1h'

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Written Verification Procedures for Authority Requests
items.question: When employees receive unusual requests (wire transfers, password resets, data access) from apparent executives or IT staff, what is your standard verification procedure?

options.label: Organization has written procedures requiring verification of unusual requests from executives or IT staff through separate communication channels
No formal verification procedures exist or employees comply immediately without verification

items.evidence_required: Written verification policy document, verification workflow diagram

items.title: Emergency Override Frequency
items.question: How often do executives or IT staff request to bypass normal security procedures due to 'emergencies' or 'urgent situations'?

options.label: Never/Rarely - Executives bypass security procedures less than monthly
Occasionally - Executives bypass security procedures monthly
Frequently - Executives bypass security procedures weekly or more often

items.evidence_required: Exception request logs from past 6 months, specific recent example
items.soc_mapping: Exception grant rate from PAM logs

items.title: Multi-Channel Verification Requirement
items.question: What verification methods are required for sensitive requests from authority figures?

options.label: Multiple verification methods required (callback, in-person, multi-channel confirmation) for sensitive requests
Single verification method used (email reply or single callback)
No verification requirements for authority figures

items.evidence_required: Verification protocol documentation, recent verification examples

items.title: Authority Impersonation Training
items.question: What specific training do employees receive on how to verify the identity of authority figures making security-related requests?

options.label: Regular training includes authority impersonation scenarios with practice verification procedures
Basic training exists but doesn't specifically cover authority impersonation
No training on verifying identity of authority figures making security requests

items.evidence_required: Training curriculum, completion records, simulation results

items.title: External Technical Expert Verification
items.question: When external technical experts, consultants, or vendors request system access or sensitive information, what verification steps are required before granting access?

options.label: Formal verification steps required before granting access to external consultants or vendors claiming technical authority
No specific protocols for verifying external technical experts

items.evidence_required: Vendor verification procedure, recent external access grant example
items.soc_mapping: External access grant logs with verification flags

items.title: Crisis Communication Authentication
items.question: During security incidents or crises, who is authorized to give direct orders that bypass normal verification procedures, and how are they authenticated?

options.label: Pre-established protocols exist for authenticating authority during security incidents with verified contact methods
No formal authentication procedures for crisis authority figures

items.evidence_required: Incident response plan, pre-authorized contact list, recent incident example
items.soc_mapping: Incident response logs with authority verification timestamps

items.title: Employee Comfort Questioning Authority
items.question: How comfortable do employees feel questioning unusual authority requests?

options.label: Employees report comfort questioning unusual authority requests and organizational policies explicitly protect verification behaviors
Mixed employee comfort levels with questioning authority figures
Strong cultural expectation not to question authority figures or executives

items.evidence_required: Employee survey results, reported suspicious request examples, cultural assessment

items.title: Executive Exception Policies
items.question: What written policies exist for when executives can authorize exceptions to standard security procedures?

options.label: Written policies explicitly state that verification is required even for executives with formal approval workflows for exceptions
Policies exist but allow exceptions for 'emergencies' or executive requests
No written policies for identity verification of authority figures

items.evidence_required: Exception policy document, recent exception approval records
items.soc_mapping: Executive exception frequency from audit logs

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: When employees receive unusual requests like wire transfers, password resets, or data access from apparent executives or IT staff, what is your standard verification procedure?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific multi-step procedure described with recent example of successful verification
scoring_guidance.yellow: General procedure mentioned but inconsistent application or no recent examples
scoring_guidance.red: No specific procedure or 'we trust our executives' response

followups.text: Can you describe the last time someone in your organization received an unusual request from apparent leadership - what exactly happened?
What would happen if an employee insisted on verification before complying with an executive request?

items.text: How often do executives or IT staff request to bypass normal security procedures due to 'emergencies' or 'urgent situations'?

scoring_guidance.green: Rare exceptions with documented justification and post-incident review
scoring_guidance.red: Frequent exceptions normalized as 'how we work'

followups.text: When did this last happen and what security steps were skipped?
How do you distinguish between legitimate emergencies and potential social engineering?

items.text: What specific training do employees receive on how to verify the identity of authority figures making security-related requests?

scoring_guidance.green: Regular simulations, role-playing, specific verification scripts provided
scoring_guidance.yellow: Generic awareness training mentioning authority but no practice
scoring_guidance.red: No authority-specific training or training focuses on 'being helpful'

followups.text: What would a junior employee do if someone claiming to be the CEO called asking for sensitive information?
Have you ever conducted simulations or role-playing exercises for authority impersonation scenarios?

items.text: During security incidents or crises, who is authorized to give direct orders that bypass normal verification procedures, and how are they authenticated?

scoring_guidance.green: Pre-authorized list with out-of-band verification methods, recent crisis example showing adherence
scoring_guidance.yellow: Informal understanding of who can authorize but no written procedures
scoring_guidance.red: Whoever claims authority during crisis is trusted

followups.text: During your last security incident or emergency, who took charge and how did people verify they were authorized?
Do you have pre-authorized incident response teams with verified contact methods?

items.text: When external technical experts, consultants, or vendors request system access or sensitive information, what verification steps are required before granting access?

scoring_guidance.green: Formal vendor verification database, multi-party approval, recent example of access denial pending verification
scoring_guidance.yellow: Basic checks performed but no formal process
scoring_guidance.red: Technical claims accepted at face value

followups.text: Describe the last time an external 'IT expert' contacted your organization - how was their identity verified?
Do you maintain a verified database of legitimate vendor and consultant contacts?

items.text: How comfortable do employees feel questioning or reporting requests from apparent authority figures that seem suspicious or unusual?

scoring_guidance.green: Multiple examples of employees questioning authority, positive outcomes, explicit protection policies
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mixed comfort levels, some employees would question but others hesitant
scoring_guidance.red: Strong cultural taboo against questioning authority

followups.text: Has anyone in your organization ever reported or questioned a suspicious request from apparent leadership? What happened to them?
Are there explicit policies protecting employees who verify authority requests?

items.text: What written policies exist for when executives can authorize exceptions to standard security procedures?

scoring_guidance.green: Documented exception process with approval workflow and regular audit
scoring_guidance.yellow: Informal understanding but no written policy
scoring_guidance.red: Executives can bypass any control at will

followups.text: Show us the most recent 'executive exception' that was granted in your organization.
How are these exceptions documented and reviewed?

solutions.title: Dual-Channel Verification Protocol
solutions.description: Require all sensitive requests from authority figures to be verified through a separate communication channel
solutions.implementation: If email request â†’ verify by phone using known numbers; if phone request â†’ verify by email
solutions.technical_controls: Email gateway flags high-risk requests (financial, access, data) for automatic verification reminders

solutions.title: Authority Authentication System
solutions.description: Deploy identity verification tools for high-risk requests
solutions.implementation: Callback verification database with confirmed phone numbers, secure communication channels for executives, MFA for authority requests bypassing normal procedures
solutions.technical_controls: PAM integration, executive contact verification database, MFA enforcement

solutions.title: Crisis Authority Protocols
solutions.description: Establish pre-authorized crisis response teams with clear authentication procedures
solutions.implementation: Pre-authorized incident response roster, verified contact methods for legitimate vendors, explicit policies that verification remains required during emergencies
solutions.technical_controls: IR playbooks with verification steps, verified vendor contact list, crisis communication channels

solutions.title: Authority Impersonation Training
solutions.description: Implement role-playing simulations where employees practice verifying apparent authority figures
solutions.implementation: Teach specific verification scripts that feel respectful rather than insubordinate, create organizational culture celebrating appropriate security verification
solutions.technical_controls: Phishing simulation platform with authority scenarios, training completion tracking, competency assessments

solutions.title: Executive Exception Management
solutions.description: Create formal approval workflows for any security exceptions
solutions.implementation: Require documented business justification and security review for executive overrides, implement logging/monitoring of all exception requests with regular review
solutions.technical_controls: Exception request workflow system, automated logging, monthly executive exception audit reports

solutions.title: Psychological Safety Programs
solutions.description: Develop explicit organizational policies protecting employees who verify authority
solutions.implementation: Create positive recognition programs for appropriate security verification behaviors, train leaders to model and encourage verification rather than viewing it as questioning authority
solutions.technical_controls: Employee reporting portal, recognition system, leadership communication templates

risk_scenarios.title: CEO Fraud / Business Email Compromise
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers impersonate executives to authorize fraudulent wire transfers, payroll redirections, or sensitive data releases
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Email impersonation with spoofed domain or compromised account
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Authority gradient makes verification feel insubordinate
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Ubiquiti Networks 2016 - $46.7M fraudulent transfers via executive impersonation

risk_scenarios.title: Fake IT Support Access
risk_scenarios.description: Criminals pose as technical support staff to gain system access, install malware, or extract credentials
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Phone call or email claiming urgent IT issue requiring user action
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Technical authority combined with helpfulness compliance
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Target 2013 - Compromised vendor credentials used to appear as authorized technicians

risk_scenarios.title: Regulatory Impersonation
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers claiming to be compliance officers, auditors, or government officials extract sensitive information or force policy violations
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Official-looking emails or calls referencing regulations/audits
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Fear of regulatory consequences prevents verification
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Anthem 2015 - Spear-phishing impersonating healthcare executives leveraging administrative hierarchy

risk_scenarios.title: Crisis Authority Hijacking
risk_scenarios.description: During security incidents, attackers insert themselves as incident response coordinators or external experts
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Appearing to help during actual breach, offering 'emergency' assistance
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Basic assumption dependency - desire for omnipotent savior during crisis
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Multiple APT campaigns maintaining persistence by posing as incident responders
